title: Requires the adoption of integrated pest management techniques at day care and child care facilities
summary: Requires the adoption of integrated pest management techniques, environmental health and safety measures and methods for limiting exposure to toxic substances at day care and child care facilities; subjects such plans to public review.

       AN ACT to amend the social services law, in relation to child day  care;
         and  to amend the environmental conservation law, in relation to inte-
         grated pest management procedures in child day care settings

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  Legislative  findings.  The legislature hereby finds that
    2  young children, including those in day care and head start centers,  are
    3  at  a  disproportionate  risk to environmental hazards such as pesticide
    4  exposure. Due to their smaller body size, developing organ  systems  and
    5  predilection for hand-to-mouth behaviors, they are exposed to and absorb
    6  more  toxic  substances  per pound of body weight than adults. Therefore
    7  the legislature finds that special protective measures, like  integrated
    8  pest management programs, are necessary.
    9    S  2.  Subdivision  3  of section 390-a of the social services law, as
   10  added by chapter 416 of the laws of 2000, paragraph (b)  as  amended  by
   11  chapter  552  of the laws of 2003 and subparagraph (ix) of paragraph (b)
   12  as amended by chapter 117 of the laws of 2010, is  amended  to  read  as
   13  follows:
   14    3.  (a)  The  office  of children and family services shall promulgate
   15  regulations  requiring  operators,  program  directors,  employees   and
   16  assistants  of  family  day  care  homes,  group  family day care homes,
   17  school-age child care programs and child day  care  centers  to  receive
   18  [thirty]  THIRTY-TWO hours of training every two years; provided, howev-
   19  er, that [fifteen] SIXTEEN hours of such training must be received with-
   20  in the first six  months  of  the  initial  licensure,  registration  or
   21  employment. Such training requirements shall also apply to any volunteer
   22  in  such  day  care homes, programs or centers who has the potential for
   23  regular and substantial contact with children. The  [thirty]  THIRTY-TWO
   24  hours of training required during the first biennial cycle after initial

    6  address the following topics:

   14    (vii) statutes and regulations pertaining to child day care;
   15    (viii)  statutes  and  regulations  pertaining  to  child  abuse   and
   16  maltreatment; [and]
   17    (ix)  for  operators,  program  directors, employees and assistants of
   18  family day care homes, group family day care homes and  child  day  care

   21    (X) ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH AND  SAFETY  MEASURES,  INCLUDING  INTEGRATED
   22  PEST  MANAGEMENT  PROCEDURES  AS DEFINED IN SUBDIVISION FIFTY OF SECTION

   24  LIMITING EXPOSURE TO TOXIC SUBSTANCES.
   25    (c)  For  the  [thirty] THIRTY-TWO hours of biennial training required
   26  after the initial period of licensure or registration, each provider who
   27  can demonstrate basic competency shall determine in which of the  speci-
   28  fied topics he or she needs further study, based on the provider's expe-
   29  rience and the needs of the children in the provider's care.
   30    (d)  Family  day  care  home  and group family day care home operators
   31  shall obtain training pertaining to protection of the health and  safety
   32  of  children,  as  required  by  regulation,  prior to the issuance of a
   33  license or registration by the office of children and family services.
   34    (e) Upon request by the office of children and  family  services,  the
   35  child  day  care applicant or provider shall submit documentation demon-

   37    S 3. Section 390-a of the social services law  is  amended  by  adding
   38  four new subdivisions 6, 7, 8 and 9 to read as follows:
   39    6.  ALL  PROVIDERS  OF  A  CHILD DAY CARE CENTER AS DEFINED IN SECTION
   40  THREE HUNDRED NINETY OF THIS TITLE, OR A  HEAD  START  DAY  CARE  CENTER
   41  FUNDED  PURSUANT  TO  TITLE V OF THE FEDERAL OPPORTUNITY ACT OF NINETEEN
   42  HUNDRED SIXTY-FOUR, AS AMENDED, ARE REQUIRED  TO  HAVE  INTEGRATED  PEST
   43  MANAGEMENT PLANS WHICH HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED WITH PUBLIC INPUT. SUCH PLANS
   44  MUST  BE  COMPLETED  WITHIN  SIX  MONTHS  OF  COMPLETION OF THE TRAINING
   45  REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH IN PARAGRAPH (B) OF  SUBDIVISION  THREE  OF  THIS
   46  SECTION.  SUCH PLANS SHALL UTILIZE INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES
   47  TO MANAGE AND CONTROL PESTS AND PROBLEMS AS DEFINED IN SUBDIVISION FIFTY
   48  OF SECTION 33-0101 OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION LAW. THE INTEGRATED
   49  PEST MANAGEMENT PLANS SHALL INCLUDE A PROVISION FOR PUBLIC ACCESS TO ALL
   50  INFORMATION ABOUT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PLANS. SUCH PROVIDERS  SHALL
   51  BE PROHIBITED FROM CONDUCTING OR HAVING CONDUCTED PESTICIDE APPLICATIONS
   52  TO  CHILD  DAY  CARE  CENTERS  AND HEAD START DAY CARE CENTERS WHICH ARE
   53  PREVENTIVE IN NATURE AND DO NOT RESPOND  TO  EXISTING,  VERIFIABLE  PEST
   54  PROBLEMS.
   55    7.  PROVIDERS  OF  A  CHILD  DAY  CARE CENTER OR A HEAD START DAY CARE
   56  CENTER SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR PROVIDING AN ANNUAL  EVALUATION  OF  THE

       A. 3851                             3

    1  IMPLEMENTATION  OF THEIR INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT PLANS TO THE PARENTS
    2  OF THE CHILDREN ATTENDING SUCH CENTER. SUCH PROVIDERS SHALL BE RESPONSI-
    3  BLE FOR UPDATING THEIR INTEGRATED  PEST  MANAGEMENT  PLANS  EVERY  THREE
    4  YEARS. SUCH INFORMATION SHALL BE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE.
    5    8.  IN  ALL  LICENSED  CHILD  DAY CARE CENTERS AND HEAD START DAY CARE
    6  CENTERS ALL PESTICIDE APPLICATIONS SHALL BE  CONDUCTED  BY  A  CERTIFIED
    7  COMMERCIAL  APPLICATOR.  PESTICIDE APPLICATIONS BY PERSONS WORKING UNDER
    8  THE DIRECT SUPERVISION OF A  CERTIFIED  PESTICIDE  APPLICATOR  SHALL  BE
    9  PROHIBITED.
   10    9.  WHEN  PESTICIDES  ARE  TO BE APPLIED TO A CHILD DAY CARE CENTER OR
   11  HEAD START DAY CARE  CENTER  GROUNDS,  TURF,  TREES  OR  SHRUBS,  VISUAL
   12  NOTIFICATION  MARKERS,  AS  PROVIDED  IN SECTION 33-1003 OF THE ENVIRON-
   13  MENTAL CONSERVATION LAW, SHALL BE POSTED AT LEAST EVERY FIFTY FEET  WITH
   14  AT LEAST ONE MARKER ON EACH SIDE OF THE APPLICATION AREA.
   15    S  4. Section 33-0101 of the environmental conservation law is amended
   16  by adding a new subdivision 50 to read as follows:
   17    50. "INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT" AND "(IPM)"  MEAN  A  DECISION-MAKING
   18  PROCESS  FOR  PEST CONTROL THAT UTILIZES REGULAR MONITORING TO DETERMINE
   19  IF AND WHEN CONTROLS ARE NEEDED; EMPLOYS PHYSICAL, MECHANICAL, CULTURAL,
   20  BIOLOGICAL AND EDUCATIONAL PRACTICES TO CONTROL CONDITIONS THAT  PROMOTE
   21  PEST  INFESTATIONS  AND  TO KEEP PEST POPULATIONS AT TOLERABLE DAMAGE OR
   22  ANNOYANCE LEVELS; AND ONLY AS A LAST RESORT, UTILIZES LEAST-TOXIC PESTI-
   23  CIDE CONTROLS. THE OVERALL GOAL OF IPM IS TO ELIMINATE  THE  UNNECESSARY
   24  USE OF PESTICIDES AND REDUCE THE USE OF ALL PESTICIDES.
   25    S  5.  This act shall take effect on the first of June next succeeding
   26  the date on which it shall have become a law.
